history.content:
For academia: the Berkeley Engineering newsletters; various news publications of our Berkeley labs; IEEE news or conference talks from the big ones like CVPR, ICRA, Hot Chips; etc. Not as knowledgeable on this, academia stuff is usually less publicized and the information is everywhere (not as centralized).

For industry: our Berkeley View From the Top talks (I think there's recordings online); Berkeley SkyDeck and other incubator media from StartX or YCombinator; news aggregators like TechCrunch, Hacker News, Reddit; industry conferences like E3/AWS re:Invent/Nvidia GTC. You can also simply search "[any of the larger EECS industry companies] tech blog" and you can probably find news and updates on what the company's recent ventures have been. Searching "[topic or company] whitepaper" can yield some interesting results too.

children.subject: I'm a big fan of Ars Technica and the /r/rust subreddit. If you're interested in Technology Policy, the Cyberlaw podcast with Stewart Baker by Steptoe and Johnson is quite good, though I think Baker's views on a number of issues (such as tech company bias are wrong; Nick Weaver (perennial Lecturer for 161 and 61C) once got into a very loud argument with Baker on the show about that) are a slightly wrong and he and his guests take a very pro-business view of most developments. I also liked The Virtual World, another podcast, though I've only listened to a few episodes.

I think the above sources are excellent and I should also just offer the suggestion that you should not just restrict yourself to tech news to stay informed about trends in technology. I would highly suggest trying to stay up to date with sources like AP Reuters (for general news), Politico (least biased source for politics I'm aware of), The Economist (Economics, International News, and more in depth analysis), Wall Street Journal (Business and other news), Lawfare (For excellent legal analysis of numerous issues including ones that affect Tech, but a little more esoteric), and others you may like. You'd be surprised at how much understanding general trends in the world informs your ability to understand technology news.

For example, the latest news regarding the Solar Winds hack and its consequences it greatly enhanced if you have an awareness of general relations between the US and Russia in the last few years. Additionally, the latest efforts by some states to sue Google over monopolistic practices is greatly enhanced if you understand the political motivations behind them. To provide one more example, the latest news regarding the Trump administration demanding ByteDance (the company owning TikTok) to divest itself from all US operations is enhanced if you understand broader trends in US-China relations during the Trump administration.

history.content: I want to start dedicating a bit of time every day to learning more about the EECS industry in general and was wondering if anyone had any advice about how to get started? Are there any podcasts or seminars (or any other kind of resource) that I can use to just learn more about what's happening in each area in this field?
history.subject: How to keep up with tech news?
